POST-SEASON GRID GAME
WITH OGLETHORPE
SCHEDULED
Hopkins Eleven Will Journey to Atlanta for Conflict on
December 10

L.

).

In response to repeated requests
received by a large number of Atlanta alumni of Johns Hopkins, the
Blue Jay grid team will play Oglethorpe University of that city in a
post-season game on December 10,
next fall. This fact was revealed
Wednesday by the Athletic Office,
and negotiations are complete with
the exception of the final signing
of the contract which has not yet
been received from Atlanta. Faculty permission has been received
and upon signing the contract the
game will be a certainty.
According to Coach Ray Van Orman, Oglethorpe is one of the leading small college elevens of the
South, and the game should be closely contested.. The Atlanta University was represented by a wonderful
grid team this season, scoring victories over Georgia Tech, the strong
Centre College, and Geneva, conquerors of Harvard, and in 1925
won the Southern Intercollegiate A.
A. football championship.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 21, 1927

ALGER HISS GETS HARVARD SCHOLARSHIP
Alger Hiss, who graduated
from Hopkins last year, has
just received the Herbert
Parker Scholarship of $250 at
the Harvard Law School, being credited with the second
highest individual ranking in
the competitive examinations.
While at Hopkins, Hiss was
a prominent figure in campus
activities, holding among other offices, the editor-in-chiefship of the NEWS-LETTER, and
the presidency of both the Student Council and the Barnstormers Club. He was also
a member of both the Phi Beta
Kappa and Omicron Delta
Kappa Honorary Societies.

A DRASTIC PROPOSAL
Buried in a very harmless-looking article on campus parking
problems in the last issue of the NEWS-LETTER is a paragraph
which is discouraging to say the least. It is concerned with puting a stop to walking on the grass of the bowl. Out of a clear
sky comes the following sentence: "The remedy at present being
debated entails the erection of two hedges, one along the bottom
and the other around the top of the bowl." Even though it would
be hard to visualize the erection of a hedge, the meaning of the
quotation seems clear enough.
The proposal is nothing to get excited over, but we don't
like it. A fringe of hedge at both the top and bottom of the bowl
could hardly be conceived as an artistic improvement. Hopkins
may not have as much of the traditional "college spirit" of the
small town institution, but in the heart of nearly every'man who
has been here long, there is a conviction, perhaps never expressed,
that the Homewood campus is beautiful, and with this belief is
coupled a feeling of pride.
We realize that some steps must be taken to Prevent the
wearing of paths on the bowl. Numerous requests have failed:
it may be that the hedge is the only solution. We feel sure, however, that if the issue is put up squarely to the students they will
prefer taking a few extra steps to seeing the bowl surrounded
by a hedge. Whether or not this proposal will entirely succeed
we cannot tell; at any• rate it deserves a trial.

THE "JOHNS HOPKINS ORCHESTRA"
Despite our protest of last week, we notice that the jazz band
playing at the Century Theatre continues to call itself the "Johns
Hopkins Orchestra." When a comfortable salary stares a man
in the face, it is not the easiest thing in the world for him to turn
it down. And similarly, when an advertising medium which
brings in the dollars is available, it is not likely that its possessor
is not going to avail himself of its use.
That seems to be the case with Enoch Light's Blue Jay Orchestra, an organization under the leadership of a graduate of the
University. While a senior at Hopkins, Light was fortunate
enough to be leader of the Blue Jay Orchestra. Upon his graduation, he organized a group of musicians, among whom are now
two Hopkins men (Light and one other), and went on the road
as the Blue Jay Orchestra. In the local daily papers he has been
advertised as the "Johns Hopkins Orchestra." Obviously, the
organization has no claim to the name "Johns Hopkins Orchestra"; it has very little right to refer to itself as "Blue Jays."
This practice of commercializing illigitimately the name of
the University is one highly to be deprecated. It is up to Light
to stop flying (playing, we should say) under false colors. His
band is not a "Johns Hopkins Orchestra," and should not parade
as such.

A DRASTIC PROPOSAL
Buried in a very harmless-looking article on campus parking
problems in the last issue of the NEWS-LETTER is a paragraph
which is discouraging to say the least. It is concerned with puting a stop to walking on the grass of the bowl. Out of a clear
sky comes the following sentence: "The remedy at present being
debated entails the erection of two hedges, one along the bottom
and the other around the top of the bowl." Even though it would
be hard to visualize the erection of a hedge, the meaning of the
quotation seems clear enough.
The proposal is nothing to get excited over, but we don't
like it. A fringe of hedge at both the top and bottom of the bowl
could hardly be conceived as an artistic improvement. Hopkins
may not have as much of the traditional "college spirit" of the
small town institution, but in the heart of nearly every'man who
has been here long, there is a conviction, perhaps never expressed,
that the Homewood campus is beautiful, and with this belief is
coupled a feeling of pride.
We realize that some steps must be taken to Prevent the
wearing of paths on the bowl. Numerous requests have failed:
it may be that the hedge is the only solution. We feel sure, however, that if the issue is put up squarely to the students they will
prefer taking a few extra steps to seeing the bowl surrounded
by a hedge. Whether or not this proposal will entirely succeed
we cannot tell; at any• rate it deserves a trial.

THE "JOHNS HOPKINS ORCHESTRA"
Despite our protest of last week, we notice that the jazz band
playing at the Century Theatre continues to call itself the "Johns
Hopkins Orchestra." When a comfortable salary stares a man
in the face, it is not the easiest thing in the world for him to turn
it down. And similarly, when an advertising medium which
brings in the dollars is available, it is not likely that its possessor
is not going to avail himself of its use.
That seems to be the case with Enoch Light's Blue Jay Orchestra, an organization under the leadership of a graduate of the
University. While a senior at Hopkins, Light was fortunate
enough to be leader of the Blue Jay Orchestra. Upon his graduation, he organized a group of musicians, among whom are now
two Hopkins men (Light and one other), and went on the road
as the Blue Jay Orchestra. In the local daily papers he has been
advertised as the "Johns Hopkins Orchestra." Obviously, the
organization has no claim to the name "Johns Hopkins Orchestra"; it has very little right to refer to itself as "Blue Jays."
This practice of commercializing illigitimately the name of
the University is one highly to be deprecated. It is up to Light
to stop flying (playing, we should say) under false colors. His
band is not a "Johns Hopkins Orchestra," and should not parade
as such.

LET'S HAVE REGULATIONS
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
As much discussion has been
aroused by the question of continuing freshman regulation, for the
next scholastic year, I would like
to set forth the following points:
(1) The regulations are a tradition. This is a fact that should be
of no importance if they were
wrong, but (2) the regulations are
used to unify the freshman class.
This alone rights any supposition of
wrong. (3) This unity is much desired. This unity produces class
